oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: United Sons and Daughters of Charity Lodge Hall
322 E. McNeal Street, Bolivar, Hardeman County, Tennessee

Color photograph of a one-story white wood panel building with red gable roof; front facade has two white doors.
The Lodge Hall's architectural significance is as largely extant example of the type of vernacular design and craftsmanship that would be found in African American community buildings constructed in small southern towns during the era of Jim Crow segregation. The building's original paneled doors, its dual entrances, and its unadorned facade speak to the building's dual function as religious and secular space within the larger white-dominated built environment of Bolivar. The dual entrance of the facade reflects a strong vernacular found in rural and small-town church architecture from the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, one that typically found women using one entrance and men using the other entrance. Thus the vernacular design conveyed to local residents the sacred use of the building.

The United Sons and Daughters of Charity was a local self-help and benevolent organization that assisted African Americans in the wake of the end of the Freedmen's Bureau and Reconstruction in Bolivar and Hardeman County. Established by a group of African American free men in 1873, it was one of several like groups to form in Tennessee during the Reconstruction Era. In 1909, the organization expanded its level of community service by purchasing a lot and building a lodge hall on E. McNeal Street in Bolivar, in a part of town which emerged in the years of reconstruction and Jim Crow as the cultural heart of the local African American community. The building burnt down in the 1920s and was rebuilt and simultaneously served as a church building for several congregations, and as a school. From 1950-1970, the Lodge Hall's significance within the landscape became even more pronounced as it became the only remaining African American cultural institution on E. McNeal Street when the other churches relocated their sanctuaries and built new edifices on the west side of town. Today it is the oldest African American building in Bolivar.
